ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PIDEMCO
(Mission and objectives)


    1. Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked the Minister for National Development (a) what is the rationale of setting up Pidemco and what are its mission and objectives; (b) under what authority Pidemco is given the right to levy a commission in handling the sales of government properties; and (c) how commission rates for different properties are determined.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, Pidemco was set up to take over some of the functions of the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and allow URA to focus on its primary role as a national planning agency. Properties formerly owned by URA were transferred to Pidemco. As a private company, Pidemco has greater flexibility in the management and promotion of the properties. It aims to become a

Column: 58

leading property company in Singapore through:

    i) upgrading its existing properties;

    ii) redeveloping some of the properties; and

    iii) developing new ones.

    Pidemco does not handle the sale of any Government properties. As a consequence, it does not receive any commission from such sales.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, is it not true that under certain circumstances, before a property can be transacted, Pidemco would have to give its permission and, under those circumstances, Pidemco would normally levy a certain administrative fee?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Member is referring to properties which Pidemco has taken over from URA. They are now Pidemco's properties. Pidemco's properties are of two kinds. Many of them are rented out on monthly

Column: 59

rentals and there are others which are sold on long-term 30-year leases. Among the 30-year leases are a number of properties which were sold at special concessionary prices to those who are affected by resettlement. In such cases, when the resettled owner wants to sell, a levy imposed on the transaction. This is to make sure that the company or the person who had obtained the site at special rates - because it is a resettlement case - does not sell and take the profit when sold at market prices. In all other cases, a nominal administrative fee, of course, is charged.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen: Sir, is it not true that under the Housing and Development rules, private developers are prevented from imposing exorbitant administrative fees? In this case, would Pidemco, as a private company, be subject to the same rules from imposing, what the market would call, such exorbitant administrative fees or, what you would call, a levy in that specific case?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have to differentiate between the two types of payments. In the first case, as I explained, if the property had been obtained under resettlement terms, they are special concessionary terms, and if the owner of the property or the lease wants to sell, then a 10% levy on the transaction is imposed. That is not an administrative fee. That is because the lessee had obtained the property at special low rates and when he sells it on the market and obtains the market price, a 10% charge is levied. But there are very few such cases. The majority of the cases would be leases sold at market rates. In such cases, it would be a purely administrative charge and my answer to the Member's query will be that Pidemco should be and will be subject to the same kind of limits as any other developer.

DETECTION OF "ICE" AMONG DRUG ABUSERS


    4. Dr Ho Tat Kin asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether "ice" or methamphetamine usage has been detected among drug abusers; and, if so, whether there are sufficient deterrents to prevent drug abusers from getting on to "ice".

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, "ice" is a crystallised form of methamphetamine which is usually consumed through smoking. The Central Narcotics Bureau has not detected any case of such drug abuse in Singapore.

    Our laws, however, have adequate provisions to deal with this problem if it should surface here. Methamphetamine is a controlled drug listed under Class B of the First Schedule of the Misuse of Drugs Act, the trafficking of which is punishable by jail sentence of at least three years and not more than 20 years and also to caning of at least three and not more than 10 strokes.

    As for those caught abusing "ice", they can be admitted to the drug rehabilitation centre for treatment and rehabilitation. In addition, they are also liable to prosecu-

Column: 61

tion in a court punishable upon conviction to a jail sentence of not more than 10 years or a fine of $20,000, or both.

Column: 61

COMMODITIES BROKING FIRMS
(Measures to regulate and monitor business activities)


    5. Dr Ho Tat Kin asked the Minister for Finance how many unlicensed commodities broking firms there are in Singapore; and what measures are being taken by the Government to regulate and monitor the business activities of these firms.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to point out that it is not accurate to refer to commodities broking firms as being unlicensed since under existing laws, there is no requirement for them to obtain a licence for conducting broking in commodity futures. However, they are properly registered with the Registry of Companies and Businesses. Members may recall that in the Second Reading of the Futures Trading Bill in March 1986, investors were advised that broking firms which offer facilities solely in commodity futures were not subject to the regulations of this legislation. Members of the public who trade with them would therefore have to accept the risk involved. Investors were advised to place their orders through members of the Singapore International Monetary Exchange Ltd (SIMEX) as their activities in commodity markets are closely monitored by the Exchange. As SIMEX members have to meet a high standard of conduct and financial requirements, the interest of investors who trade through them would be protected. Currently, there are 15 SIMEX members which offer services in broking commodity futures in addition to financial futures.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT

12.38 pm

    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [2nd March, 1990],

    That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 1990 to 31st March, 1991.". - [Minister for Finance].

    Question again proposed.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Tiong Bahru GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the

Column: 62

motion standing in the name of the Minister for Finance.

    First, I wish to congratulate the Minister on his friendly Budget and thank him for returning to the public in the form of the 5% one-time personal tax rebate, the family and procreation tax incentives, lower corporate tax and other reliefs.

    Sir, studying the Budget, one cannot help but feel that the recession of 1985 is a long time ago. That we have recovered from that recession to register such strong growth in the last two years is a fitting tribute to our nation's 25th anniversary. It is a fitting tribute to the Government for its very able and expert handling of the economy and to our people for having the quiet resilience to pull ourselves together.

    It is no less an amazing feat that within five years of a recession, the Minister is able to present a Budget which has very quickly become a non-event - with its complete absence of bad news - not even for drinkers and smokers.

    To me, Sir, the Budget is not just a celebration budget as headlined in the Straits Times. It is a commonsense Budget. From the 1985 recession, we have always been mindful of the integration of our economy in the international business grid and that we face continual competition from other newly industrialising economies. It is therefore commonsense that we must continually fashion our fiscal policies to match. It is commonsense that our fiscal policies must be attractive to retain our talented and enterprising as they possess skills which are internationally tradeable. It is commonsense that by returning to the people more in the way of tax rebates it can actually add more to the economy as a whole. It is not a zero-sum situation. Lastly, Sir, it is, or should be, commonsense that the option of having a good news budget is dependent on sustained economic growth and pragmatic and sound Government. Allow me now to comment on some of the key issues and measures announced in the Budget.

Procreation Incentives

    While the series of incentives is good and necessary to redress our population

Column: 63

problem, releasing these a little at a time, year to year, may, in my mind, have adverse effects. It could cause some unmarried Singaporeans, or childless couples, to wait another year to see what extras they may receive in the next year's budget. This may be self-defeating to some extent. Tinkering with the goings-on in our people's bedrooms is always a hazardous exercise, but greater circumspection should be observed in tackling this subject. Therefore, we should give the measures time to work. Just like courtship, there should be a cooling off period at times for a successful suit.

    Sir, I must point that the new incentives have created some rumbles among some of our better educated unmarried female Singaporeans. Some, I hear, are complaining that the declining scale in tax rebates for procreation could equate the value of our unmarried women to that of an old car under our PARF and new vehicle quota system. By reducing the quantum of tax benefit for child-bearing as a woman gets older, we may also be reducing the marriage prospects of our better educated unmarried Singaporean women. Their value is now equated with the reducing value of a car quota licence as the years expire. Before the age of 28, Sir, the unmarried woman's worth to the prospective groom in terms of procreation tax incentives is $20,000; and this value drops progressively and very quickly.

Consumption Tax

    Last year, I supported in this House the imposition of a consumption tax. But I am pleased to note that the Minister has decided to hold off imposition of a tax on consumption until such time as it may be needed. While agreeing with the principle of such a tax, ie, shifting direct tax to indirect taxation and giving the individual a greater measure of personal choice in his expenditure pattern, it should be delayed as long as possible.

    Careful study must be made to ensure that it does not hurt the lower income group. It will definitely hit the higher spending middle income group who will

Column: 64

again end up paying more in taxes. To offset this, the Minister should review the tax system and reduce personal income tax correspondingly or introduce other personal reliefs for the taxpayer. This is to establish the principle that indirect taxation is to offset direct taxation.

    The experience of other countries has shown that such a consumption tax tends to have an escalating nature and will create a "black economy" where people evade the tax through exchange of goods and services through bartering. There are many areas and issues to be ironed out before this tax is imposed.

Personal Income Tax

    I turn now to personal income tax. The Minister must be thanked for granting a 5% one-time personal income tax rebate, given perhaps in the spirit of celebrating 25 years of independence. In that same spirit, Sir, he could repeat what was done in 1986 and up the rebate to 25% instead - 25th anniversary, 25% rebate. This will be a real celebration which would definitely make life much better, especially to our "beleaguered" middle income who are already suffering from higher car taxes and what-nots.

    In 1986, the Minister, in reducing the rates of corporate tax, expounded the principle that the top rate should be in line with the personal income tax. It is surprising to me that the Minister has not sought to standardise the maximum rate of personal income tax from 33% to 31% now that corporate tax has been reduced by another 1% to 31%. This 2% disparity may encourage businessmen and other professionals to resort to tax avoidance measures so as to avoid paying the extra 2% in personal tax. Perhaps it is time for the Government to review the entire tax structure. Such annual largesse, be it 5% or 2%, while welcomed, also gives cause for uncertainty as to what the Minister might design to distribute the following year.

Cost of Doing Business

    The Budget has proved painless for the business community. However, the cost of doing business has gone up in recent

Column: 65

years -what with higher office rentals, motor vehicle taxes for both cars and commercial vehicles, higher car parking charges, and higher CPF rates.

    As costs are already high, the Government should observe caution in implementing the increase in employer's CPF contribution in July, to ensure it does not damage our international competitiveness as a business centre. In this respect, Sir, I welcome the relaxation on the employment of foreign workers. This not only reduces the cost of doing business but actually makes business much easier to do. Without workers, doing business in Singapore is difficult.

    The Minister has announced his intention to focus on the private sector as an engine for further growth in Singapore. Although he has reinstated his intention, it should have broached further on the subject of privatisation. Besides the statutory boards, there are a number of Government-owned companies which are suitable for privatisation. The free market principles have served us well and the path we have followed should be less government where less is needed, and government only when it is sorely needed.

    Privatisation of our large Government corporations has many benefits: removal of the government as a backstop against failure is more likely than not to improve efficiency and provide incentive for profit. But of greater importance is the floodgate which such a move could release: we will be providing the environment for them to move abroad to sell their services and expertise.

    Some of our statutory boards, like the Jurong Town Corporation and the Port of Singapore Authority, are already doing so. These large corporations have the expertise and the capability to market themselves abroad and provide a valuable service to other countries. We should provide the necessary incentives and create the scenario for them to do so. Privatisation is one such way. Infusion of managers from the private sector, imposition of a corporate tax structure on statutory boards similar to the private sector, are bound to make them more competitive and accountable. If private enterprises

Column: 66

could be allowed to enter the areas currently monopolised by such statutory boards, we lay the groundwork for greater competition, efficiency and profitability, all to the good of our country in the long run. Privatisation will also allow some of our senior civil servants, who are heading such statutory boards on corporations to become captains of industry, and move out of the civil service structure. Otherwise, such dual roles can give the public and international businesses wrong signals, eg, that such organisations, because they are headed by a senior civil servant, are therefore special. They may be perceived as enjoying special privileges and clout and we may not be able then to ensure fair competition and improve efficiency in our economy.

Vision of 1999

    As this is 1990, and we have a special date with 1999, I was expecting more from the Budget in directing our efforts to reach our vision of 1999. Hence, I cannot in all honesty call our Budget for 1990 a creative one. If anything, we may at best call it a procreative budget, but not something that takes us beyond 1990 and into the 1990s.

    While the Budget and tax packages reflect the buoyant mood of our economy and country, it lacks specific direction, especially as it is the first year of our entry into the 1990s. This is, we are told, the decade when Singapore is supposed to achieve the status of a developed country, and achieve the standard of living of the Switzerland of today. There is, I submit, a lack of strategic direction in trying to attain that state, or to fashion Singapore after the economy and standard of living of the Swiss. There seems to be a lack of the master plan for achieving that status and making Singapore an even better place to live in. The 1990 Budget does not lay the foundation or structure for promotion of that society.

    We have entered that phase in our nation's history when our minds turn from the basics of making a living to the arts and to a better quality of life in all its tangible and intangible forms. The Budget is preoccupied with procreation in industry

Column: 67

and in the bedroom, but forgets to prolong the pleasure that should follow after that. Lest I be accused of being too critical, I shall respectfully submit for the Minister's consideration what I shall call my wish list.

Wish No. 1

    This concerns the quality of life in Singapore. Now that we have provided the incentives for our population to procreate, how about making life and living more creative for the offspring? Singaporeans today enjoy one of the highest standards of living in the world, at least materially. They have comfortable homes, abundant food, good educational, health and other social services, an efficient transportation system, more recreational facilities, easily available swimming pools in housing estates, our own symphony orchestra, Swing Singapore and more entertainment outlets. Yet, we hear the oft-repeated remark - "nothing much to do in Singapore". This is due in no small way to rising affluence and more free time. Our leaders speak of creating space outside Singapore, yet the 1990 Budget does not provide us with such a blue print. Allow me to comment on some areas which go towards creating a better quality of life.

Performing Arts

    I would like to direct the Minister's attention to the entertainment industry. Taxes on the performing arts and those engaged in it have remained largely unchanged over the years, though the hefty entertainment duty on each ticket sold has been reduced to 10%. Due to our small market, impresarios and other entertainment companies have to incur large costs to bring in foreign entertainers. Coupled with other costs and imponderables, it makes these ventures highly hazardous for those in the industry. A number of publicised failures suggest that we may not be doing enough to promote this area of our leisure pursuits or cultural life.

    It is timely, as we enter the 1990s, to review the entire entertainment tax system and set as a national goal the development of the performing arts and better recrea-

Column: 68

tional services. We should place such projects on the same plane as our economic development.

    It should be conceivable that we accord to the industry the same pioneer status tax incentives and development assistance that we accord businesses under our economic development plan. Apart from raising the quality of life in Singapore, we would be developing yet another service industry which will be another source of revenue for Singapore.

    To encourage big corporation sponsorships to provide more funds for the arts and recreational activities, the Government could make sponsorship even more attractive. One way is the introduction of double taxation relief for those contributions for sponsorship of such activities. Other ways could be devised as well, so that such companies contribute not merely as a public relations measure but to do so because of greater commitment towards the national goal of raising the quality of life in Singapore.

    To create space outside Singapore, the Minister may like to fashion some incentives for private enterprises to invest overseas. Such incentives are for the creation of large recreational projects which may be enjoyed by Singaporeans. Hence, instead of just urging Singaporeans to create space outside Singapore, the Government must take a lead and the offer of incentives is a clear indication of the Government's intent.

Wish No. 2

    Sir, the Switzerland of today has a number of well-known multinationals in the food, medical, industrial and consumer goods industries. These multinational corporations are not only a source of national strength and pride, it in a way creates space by offering employment to their nationals outside Switzerland.

    To tap the world market, most countries must rely on the larger enterprises, especially the MNCs. Singapore should follow that route. It can do so by stimulating the creation of MNCs through fiscal measures and offer incentives for Singapore companies to go overseas. We may do so on a

Column: 69

selective basis by targeting the industry and the size of the corporation which it wants to encourage. The Minister could have announced the groundwork for such a development for Singapore - or perhaps he already has a master plan but is keeping it very close to his chest.

    However, the Budget does not outline any such fiscal measures to develop our own MNCs or to create the environment for our larger corporations to launch more effective forays into the international market and carve a niche for themselves internationally. We have our Yeo Hiap Sengs and F & Ns who have achieved some measure of success in selling their goods abroad, and establishing manufacturing plants in other countries. But are they MNCs? Are they selling franchise abroad and making significant inroads into other countries? Are they on their way to becoming the Coca-Colas and Pepsi-Colas of Singapore? In my view, Sir, on their own, they are not. But together, they have considerable muscle and clout, which make this possible.

    Could the Minister help to bring this about by perhaps creating a tax structure for some of our larger companies to merge and pool their resources for faster growth in the international market?

    Let me end, Sir, by thanking the Minister for his celebration Budget. However, Singaporeans would have a little more to celebrate if the Budget had also addressed my wish list which is more than the nuts and bolts of an equation on revenue and expenditure.
12.57 pm

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the Minister for Finance's Budget.

    The budget which comprise a series of tax incentives and tax rebates has brought joy to the people of Singapore and is well received by them. I appreciate very much the sound and prudent budget put forward by the Minister.

    The various tax incentives will surely help to promote our economic growth. At the same time, the budget also takes

Column: 70

cognizance of the livelihood of our people and will surely benefit them. I hope such tax measures will be further improved on and that more of them will be forthcoming to benefit our people.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, after studying this year's budget, our people will be able to see clearly and, from their personal experience, realize how the PAP Government in the past 25 years has made sacrifices and contributions towards making Singapore a well-governed country. Not only is the Government far-sighted in carrying out long term plans and sound financial policy so as to promote all-embracing economic developments, it has also formulated a comprehensive programme to lead our people towards a better life and our nation towards great heights.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, budget has come at a very opportune moment and has shown that the Government is not merely interested in accumulating reserves and that the various Government ministries are not merely interested in collecting more revenues, earning more surpluses or levying all kinds of taxes. Without shirking its responsibilities, the Government has embarked on the course of privatising certain departments and services which have been under their charge, in order to earn more profits. On the contrary, the Government has always tried its best to serve the people, to govern the country well and to ensure the prosperity and progress of our nation. The various tax incentives and tax rebates contained in the budget show that as long as our economy continues to grow and whenever conditions permit, the Government will inject some of our budget surpluses into our economy by way of tax rebates and tax concessions to further stimulate our economic growth while, at the same time, return more money into the hands of the people for them to decide how to spend it.

    The reserves accumulated by the Government over the years are intended to ensure that our nation and people have enough means and financial resources to deal with emergency situations, such as an economic recession or a downturn in our economy, so that we have something to

Column: 71

fall back on. It is a philosophy of taking measures to deal with any untoward eventuality.

    However, if we want to convince our people that the greater their contributions towards the development of our country, the greater will be their shares in the fruits of their labour, then we must make sure that we have to be cautious in implementing certain policies. Full attention must be given to the details of policy implementation. Also, greater considerations should be given to their sensitivities when these policies affect them.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, while most of the people react favourably to the budget, I still have two observations to make and I hope the Minister will take note of them.

    First, tax incentives on procreation. A woman who has a second baby before she is 31 years old will be given a special tax rebate. This is a very innovative tax incentive. It shows how the Government is encouraging our young men and women who are of marriageable age to get married and have babies earlier to ensure a normal growth in our population. This is a correct policy measure. But those working women who got married after they were 30 years old and who have already had one child will not be able to benefit if they wish to have one or two more children. This is because when they had their second or third child they would have been well over 31 years old which is the age limit for such tax rebates.

    There are many reasons why these young couples got married late. Some had to support their aged parents or assist their younger siblings to complete their education. Some could not get married earlier because they did not have the means or for other personal reasons, they had to postpone their marriage until they were 30 years old and had children after that. Though some couples were married at 25 years old they did not have their first baby until they were 31 years old because one of the spouses had suffered certain physiological problems.
